bibl.title: Letter fragment to Margaret Deland, January 16, 1928

div1.p: The writer informs Deland that he is continuing to lobby Congress for the pension bill.

div1.head: Letter fragment to Margaret Deland, January 16, 1928
div1.p:
You must think my long delay in answering your kind letter of last
August inexcusable. But I had to pay a second time for my activity in
behalf of those Yellow Fever Heroes by another nervous breakdown, which
lasted for nearly five months. The job of conducting a department in
one of these big City High Schools is about enough to keep a man busy.
So when one is fool enough to take on several additional tasks, he has
to settle for his folly. But this business is far more worth while than
ridding Scarsdale of flies and mosquitoes, protecting its shade trees,
and supplying bird houses--a series of projects my son and I enjoyed
when we lived in that neighboring town.

If you have the patience to read over some of the enclosures you
will see that the work has gone on, and that we really have hope of some
kind of a victory in the near future. Here's hoping, anyhow. Just as
soon as we decide on the form of the legislation desired, I will let you
know, for we are sure we can count on your active support. We hope you
may get in touch with your members of Congress from Maine, for we can
hope to accomplish the desired end only by personal work all over the
country. I am to lecture to our Lions Club next week, and they promise
to get their National Organization to take action. In the same way we
hope to get busy the Rotary Clubs, the Kiwanis, and the Veterans' Organiza-
tions to get busy.

I certainly would like much to read over your article on sex education,
especially since that is the subject we plan to discuss in our Senior
boys and girls classes this term. I will return it soon. May I show it
to our teachers? You will be interested in a letter Dr. Fosdick was
good enough to write me
